block.p: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
Opera

''CARMEN.'' The first production of the Opera Festival of New Jersey is Bizet's ''Carmen,'' one of the most popular operas ever written. But this inventive company, which performs only in the summer at the McCarter Theater on the campus of Princeton University, has more unusual productions lined up for later in the season, including Hugo Weisgall's ''Six Characters in Search of an Author'' and Princeton native Frank Lewin's ''Burning Bright.'' Verdi's ''Falstaff'' rounds out the season. ''Carmen'' will feature Suzanna Guzman in the title role, Gerald Powers as Don Jose and Kristopher Irmiter as Escamillo. Michael Ching conducts and Elizabeth Bachman, in her festival debut, is the stage director. Tomorrow's performance at 8 p.m. is the opening night gala. The gala dinner beforehand costs $150 per person. But the post-performance festivities in the theater lobby are free to all; cocktails are at 5 p.m., dinner at 6. McCarter Theater, Princeton University, 91 University Place, Princeton, N.J. Tickets: $24-$82. For tickets, information and directions, call: (609) 258-2787; gala information, (609) 279-1750 (Anthony Tommasini).

''MARRIAGE OF FIGARO.'' The homespun but attractive qualities of the Amato Opera's productions and the intimacy of its shoe-box theater offer a useful change of perspective for operagoers used to the big houses uptown. The casts here vary: the singers are eager and enthusiastic, and sometimes promising, and Anthony Amato, the company's founder, conducts the performances with an evident love of the music. The performances this weekend close the season, and tomorrow evening's show will also include a celebration of Mr. Amato's 80th birthday. Tomorrow at 7 p.m., Sunday at 2:30 p.m. Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village. Tickets: tomorrow evening's performance is $50; the Sunday performance is $25; $20 for the elderly and children; (212) 228-8200 (Allan Kozinn).

''RIGOLETTO'' and ''MADAMA BUTTERFLY.'' This summer marks the 34th consecutive year of the Met in the Parks, the Metropolitan Opera's popular and free series of operas in concert performance. Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' opened on Tuesday in Central Park with a fine cast, headed by Carlo Guelfi in the title role. An alternate cast will sing tonight's performance in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx: Frederick Burchinal as Rigoletto, Jonathan Welch as the Duke of Mantua and Jennifer Welch as Gilda. Nello Santi conducts. Tomorrow night in Van Cortland Park in the Bronx, a highly-touted Hungarian soprano, Georgina Lukacs, in her first appearance with the Met, will sing the title role of ''Madama Butterfly,'' with Paul Charles Clarke as the callow American naval lieutenant B. F. Pinkerton. Julius Rudel will conduct. ''Rigoletto: Pelham Bay Park, Bronx; today at 8 p.m. ''Madama Butterfly: Van Cortland Park, Bronx; tomorrow at 8 p.m. Performances are free; information, (212) 362-6000 (Tommasini).
Classical Music

BARGEMUSIC. There are few better places in the city to hear chamber music than this barge floating on the East River, with its live, intimate acoustics and its spectacular view of Lower Manhattan. Good weather will only enhance the experience, and the performances are often as fine as the setting. Here, in programs coordinated by Toby Hoffman, a violist, he is joined by other performers, including Peter Nagy, a pianist, and Colin Carr, a cellist. The big piece tonight and tomorrow is Brahms's G minor Piano Quartet (the one Schoenberg gussied up for orchestra); on Sunday, it is Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, and Sunday at 4 p.m., Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $27; $25 for the elderly; $15 for students (James R. Oestreich).

GOLDMAN MEMORIAL BAND. Outdoor concerts by concert bands can be a hard sell these days: the repertory generally has an olden quality, marches and galops not being especially in vogue now, and the amplification that is usually necessary to help these groups compete with traffic exact a cost on whatever subtlety the playing may show. Still, the Goldman Memorial Band, which traces its roots to 1911, tends to draw fairly large crowds to its free summer performances. Its program this weekend is to be conducted by David Eaton and includes the premiere of ''The New York Times Color March,'' a work by Carl Schlesinger, a retired printer at The New York Times who wanted to commemorate the newspaper's introduction of color photographs, illustrations and advertisements in 1997. Also on the program is a tribute to the Manhattan School of Music, with works by John Corigliano, Vittorio Giannini and a commissioned work by Drew Hemenger, a doctoral candidate at the school. Sunday: 6 p.m. at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center (212) 807-4915. Admission is free. (Kozinn).

MANNES BACH INSTITUTE. It is nice to see that the blockbuster commemorations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death this year have not entirely crowded out more intimate affairs. The Mannes College of Music here concludes a two-week institute on Bach performance, which has included concerts by faculty members and students. Appropriately, the final event is devoted to the students newly groomed, offering selected arias as well as works featuring cello, flute and other instruments. Tonight at 8, Mannes Concert Hall, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan, (212) 580-0210, ext 277. Admission: free (Oestreich).

MAVERICK CONCERTS. This enterprising chamber music series, in its 85th season, offers concerts in an open-sided barn where the sounds of nature and the music of man interact freely. It is opening its season with what it calls a Prelude Concert, with performances by Steven Lubin, the pianist, and Danielle Woerner, the soprano. Also on the program is Mary Louise Wilson's play, ''There's a Deer in My Soup,'' and a community sing with the Ars Coralis choir. Saturday at 5 p.m. Maverick Road between Routes 28 and 375, West Hurley, N.Y., just outside Woodstock. (914) 679-8217 Tickets: $15. (Kozinn).
Dance

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER. Martine van Hamel returns to the company as Madge the witch in ''La Sylphide'' tomorrow night, preceded by Robert Joffrey's ''Pas de Deesses.'' August Bournonville's delectable fairy-tale ballet about a sylph who falls in love with a Scotsman will follow Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas'' tonight and tomorrow afternoon. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $75. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 362-6000 Matinee-goers can brush up on their Bournonville at ''ABTalks,'' a free pre-performance discussion featuring the dance writer Elizabeth Kaye at 12:45 p.m. in the theater (Jennifer Dunning).

LAZ BREZER. A charter member of Kei Takei's Moving Earth, Laz Brezer will perform in dances by himself and Ms. Takei, a new piece by Daniel Nagrin and a collaboration with the avant-garde circus producer Keiichi Nishida. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 (tonight and tomorrow); $15 (Sunday). La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East 4th Street, East Village; (212) 475-7710 (Dunning).

DANCE FOR JOY MINISTRIES. Even the most committed atheist would probably admit that there is an almost religious sense of exaltation at the heart of dance. Dance for Joy Ministries, a 30-member company founded and directed by Iris Cloud, formerly with Dance Theater of Harlem, seasons its style of ballet and liturgical dance with joy in an attempt to share the gospel through dance. Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $25. TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street . The Ministries' Workshop Showcase Celebration, featuring students of all ages from its school, will be presented on June 25 at 4 p.m. Tickets: $10. TriBeCa Performing Arts Center; (212) 346-8510 or (212) 571-2644, extension 902 (Dunning).

DANCE GALAXY. Ballet for grownup audiences performed by grown-up audiences will be presented by Dance Galaxy, founded recently by the dancers Judith Fugate and Medhi Bahiri. The program includes new ballets by Ann Marie D'Angelo and Adam Miller and works by George Balanchine, Daniel Levans and Toni Pimble. Tonight at 7:30. Tickets: $25; $15 for children between 6 and 14. Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street; the show is tonight at 7:30; (212) 874-1061 (Dunning).

DANCERS RESPONDING TO AIDS: ''PURE MOTION.'' Julio Bocca will star in this benefit for Dancers Responding to AIDS and the Community Research Initiative on AIDS, which also features choreography by Desmond Richardson and Mark Dendy. Tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $35 (general seating); $50 (reserved seating); $200 and $500 (performance and cocktails). Theater at East Hampton High School, East Hampton, N.Y.; (212) 840-0770 (Dunning).

DANSPACE PROJECT: DRAFT WORK. This free series of informal showings of works in progress features Jeanine Durning and Cheng-Chieh Yu in their collaborative duet ''A Tree Plus a Tree Is a Forest.'' Tomorrow at 3 p.m. Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street; (212) 674-8194 (Dunning).

MARTITA GOSHEN'S EARTHWORKS. A visionary conservationist as well as a choreographer, Martita Goshen will present a world premiere benefit performance of ''Threshold,'' part of a series devoted to what Ms. Goshen refers to as ''a return to the old ways of listening to mother earth.'' The dance will be accompanied by film shot in Greece and Ireland, with music by composers who include Glen Velez. Tonight at 8. Tickets: $12 to $25. Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues; (212) 772-448; (Dunning).

JACOB'S PILLOW DANCE FESTIVAL. The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opens its 68th season at a gala featuring Julie Taymor, with sneak previews of work by the festival's opening-week companies, Garth Fagan Dance and the new RhythMEK, founded by the former Ailey dancers Michael Thomas, Elizabeth Roxas and Karine Plantadit-Bageot. The evening begins with a Champagne reception and includes dinner and previews of two exhibits, one of photographs by Jack Mitchell and the other of artwork by the choreographer Paul Taylor. Tomorrow at 5 p.m. Tickets: $200 to $500. Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, Becket, Mass.; (413) 637-1322, extension 25 (Dunning).

NETA DANCE COMPANY. Neta Pulvermacher choreographically collaborates with XTC, an English rock band, to create ''The Orchid Show,'' an evening-length work set in a psychedelic swamp where mortals and supernatural folk mingle and tales are told in dance and music about orchids and the people who collect and adore them. Tonight and tomorrow at 8, Sunday at 3 and 8 p.m., the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793 extension 11. Tickets: $20 general admission, $15 for dancers (Jack Anderson).

NEW DANCE ALLIANCE PERFORMANCE MIX. Fifteen choreographers, companies and small ensembles will present work in three different programs in this always interesting series, directed by Karen Bernard. Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $5 for students and the elderly; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street; (212) 334-7479 (Dunning).

NEW YORK CITY BALLET. Company director Peter Martins will present a new ballet in an all-Martins program (tomorrow night), in a weekend that also includes the George Balanchine-Alexandra Danilova ''Coppelia'' (tonight) and works by Balanchine and Jerome Robbins. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $72; $10 for student rush tickets. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; (212) 870-5570. The company will also present a ''Ballet Insights'' pre-performance discussion program featuring company pianist Cameron Grant on modern music in ballet. Tomorrow at 6:45 p.m. Tickets: $5. Kaplan Penthouse, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; (212) 870-4074 (Dunning).

92ND STREET Y: FRIDAYS @ NOON. This free series of new dances and works in progress ends its season with choreography by Brad Mackenzie, Maja Lorkovic, Raymundo Costa and Heather Harrington. Today at noon. 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; (212) 996-1100 (Dunning).

OUTRAGEOUS JOY. And the award for the best company name goes to . . . Outrageous Joy. The choreographers are Karen L. Arceneaux, M'Bewe Escobar, Sharon Wong and Steven E. Brown. Today and tomorrow at 8:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12; $8 for students. Bridge for Dance, 2726 Broadway, near 104th Street; (212) 749-1126 (Dunning).

PARALLEL EXIT. Created by the company members of Parallel Exit, a dance and theater troupe from Toronto, ''Velo/City'' blends acrobatics, vaudeville and a short film in a piece about a day in the life of three identical urban office workers. Today through Sunday (and Wednesday through Sunday through July 2) at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $12. Walkerspace, 46 Walker Street, south of Canal Street between Broadway and Church Street; (212) 662-1080 (Dunning).

PARSONS DANCE COMPANY. David Parsons fills his company's programs with works by himself and Robert Battle, many to live music by the Elm City Ensemble. The theatrically ingenious productions include multimedia mixtures of dancing and photography and dancing and strobe lights. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $35 (Anderson).

THE SOULS OF OUR FEET. This new festival, sponsored by the Thellma Hill Performing Arts Center, will present ''Toenails of Steel and Ruby Red Text,'' a program featuring dance by Malcolm Low, Baraka de Soleil, Ron K. Brown, and Richard Rivera and writing by Gale Jackson, Stacyann Chin, Cheryl Boyce Taylor, and Mary Jade Whitehead. The program addresses gay black life. The curators are Ron K. Brown and Cheryl Boyce Taylor. Tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $8 for students and the elderly. Triangle Theater, Long Island University, Brooklyn; (718) 875-9710 (Dunning).

SUDDEN ENLIGHTENMENT THEATER In her new ''Tae: The Umbilical Cord,'' Eun-Hee Kim juxtaposes an ancient Korean creation myth with symbols of the fragmentation and isolation of life today. There will also be modern dance from Hey Jeong Yoon, with music by Carman Moore. Today through Sunday at 8 p.m., and Sunday at 3 p.m.. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly. Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, Morningside Heights; (212) 870-6784 (Dunning).

TANGO & TANGO. Need one say more? Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and the elderly; $5 for high school students through the High 5 Tickets to the Arts Program. Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens; (718) 729-3880 (Dunning).

THALIA OUTDOORS. Free hourlong programs of music and dance from Spain and Mexico. Sundays through June at 1 p.m. Thomson Hill Park, Noonan Playground, Greenpoint Avenue, between 42nd and 43rd Streets, Sunnyside, Queens; (718) 729-3880 (Dunning).

''THEME AND VARIATIONS.'' Images from ballet, lyrical and full of passion, will be on view in an exhibit by the dance photographer known as Costas. The exhibit also includes dance sculptures by Andrew De Vries, paintings by Douglas Hofmann and aquatints by Roy Fairchild-Woodard. Today and tomorrow (and Monday through Saturday through July 1) from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. The Gallery at Lincoln Center, concourse level, just beneath the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 580-4673 (Dunning)

CHEMICAL WEDDING. Dance, video and fascinatingly weird electronic performance-affecting gizmos by the interactive performance pioneers Dawn Stoppiello and Mark Coniglio. Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village; (212) 647-0202 (Dunning).

THREE POINT JUNCTURE. Yanira Castro and Company, Mills and Payne Dance and Pam Tanowitz/Open 24 Hours Dance Company join forces in a program of works about such themes as daily routines, traditional rituals, a childlike world of games and a choreographer's personal life. Tonight and tomorrow at 8, TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street; (212) 346-8510. Tickets: $15 (Anderson).

LYNNE WELLS. A troupe of performers from the companies of Jennifer Muller, Tango Mujer and the Pittsburgh Opera will dance choreography by Lynne Wells and Leda Meredith. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $15. Gene Frankel Theater, 24 Bond Street, two block north of Houston and east of Lafayette Streets; (718) 832-1598 (Dunning).
